docs.lead_paragraph: Walter J. McNerney, who oversaw the integration of Blue Cross and Blue Shield and gave shape to the Congressional debate leading to Medicare and Medicaid, died on July 29 at his home in Winnetka, Ill. He was 80. His death was announced by Northwestern University, where he retired in 1999 as Herman Smith professor emeritus of health policy at the university's Kellogg School of Management. He joined the faculty in 1982 and for many years taught the advanced health policy course at Kellogg, the graduate business school.

headline.main: Walter McNerney, 80, Dies; Helped Shape Health Policy

docs.snippet: Walter J. McNerney oversaw the integration of Blue Cross and Blue Shield and gave shape to the Congressional debate leading to Medicare and Medicaid.

docs.lead_paragraph: HEALTH savings accounts, a sort of I.R.A. for health care, let people set aside money tax-free to pay for medical expenses, both now and later. But the accounts have been controversial since their introduction in January 2004. Depending on whom you ask, they are either a wonderful tool to help Americans become wiser, more price-conscious health care consumers, or just another way for employers to pass along more health care expenses to their workers. Critics also contend that the accounts are basically a tax-shelter gimmick for people who are healthy and wealthy enough to invest in them but don't have to rely on them to cover their care costs.

headline.main: The Promise and the Pitfalls Of Health Savings Accounts

docs.snippet: Depending on whom you ask, health savings accounts are either a tool to help Americans become more price-conscious, or another way for employers to pass along expenses to workers.

docs.lead_paragraph: Battle-hardened by the medical system, patients have become pretty good at taking care of one another. If they are not learning enough from their doctors about diagnoses and treatment options, they can turn to organizations that offer support and education programs for specific illnesses. Doctors can often make recommendations about which of these groups are reliable. Another worthy resource is the patient advocate, a relatively new role with fluid responsibilities. Many hospitals employ advocates to resolve disputes between patients and staff members, including doctors; they can also help patients who face difficult treatment decisions.

headline.main: Patients Turn To Advocates, Support Groups And E-Mail, Too

docs.snippet: Battle-hardened by the medical system, patients have become pretty good at taking care of one another. If they are not learning enough from their doctors about diagnoses and treatment options, they can turn to organizations that offer support and...

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Brigid K. Killelea, a daughter of Mary-Rita and James K. Killelea of Branford, Conn., was married at her parents' house last evening to Chad M. Czapla, a son of Nancy and Edward Czapla of West Hartford, Conn. The Rev. George Koury, a Unity minister, officiated. Dr. Czapla, 35, is studying outcomes in pediatric surgery as part of a two-year research fellowship at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. A graduate of Colgate, the bride received a master's in public health from Johns Hopkins and her medical degree from the University of Connecticut. Her mother is a reading specialist at Simon Lake School in Milford, Conn. Her father, who retired as general counsel of the Crum & Forster Insurance Company in Morristown, N.J., is now a lawyer handling reinsurance and arbitration issues at Reinsurance Solutions International in Manhattan.
docs.snippet: Dr. Brigid K. Killelea, a daughter of Mary-Rita and James K. Killelea of Branford, Conn., was married at her parents' house last evening to Chad M. Czapla, a son of Nancy and Edward Czapla of West Hartford, Conn. The Rev. George Koury, a Unity...

docs.lead_paragraph: On and on they go, mammoth lawsuits against the nation's biggest tobacco companies. Just two weeks ago, Philip Morris USA and five other cigarette makers were sued in a federal court in Boston by a group seeking to recover $60 billion for the government in Medicare benefits for smoking-related diseases. Lawyers for the group, the United Seniors Association, said the law also allowed the court to award an additional $60 billion to the plaintiff.

headline.main: Big Tobacco, in Court Again. But the Stock Is Still Up.

docs.snippet: Two weeks ago, Philip Morris USA and five other cigarette makers were sued for $60 billion. But the industry long ago accepted litigation as a routine cost of business.

docs.lead_paragraph: For the first time since the residential real estate marathon began 13 years ago, parts of the country are showing signs of exhaustion. But if you rely on the experts to declare that a particular area's bubble has popped, you may have waited too long. So how can a homeowner tell if a market is about to go bust? This may be one of those rare occasions when professionals parsing data are at a disadvantage to regular people watching the market. That's because the main driver of today's market is consumer psychology. Home prices go up as long as people expect them to go up.

headline.main: Do Try This at Home: Assess Your Area's Real Estate Bubble

docs.snippet: The residential real estate marathon is showing signs of exhaustion, but don't rely on experts to declare that a particular area's bubble has popped.

docs.lead_paragraph: In the latest chapter of a scandal that has clouded the administration of County Executive Thomas R. Suozzi, a former assistant to a top Nassau official was arrested Wednesday on charges of grand larceny, accused of stealing county funds by filing time sheets for work he did not perform. The former assistant, Shomwa Shamapande, was charged with taking $12,000 in pay he was not entitled to, said District Attorney Denis Dillon. Mr. Shamapande pleaded not guilty in the Nassau County First District Court in Hempstead and was released on his own recognizance.

headline.main: Former Nassau Parks Aide Arrested Amid Payroll Inquiry

docs.snippet: A former assistant to a top Nassau official was arrested Wednesday on charges of grand larceny, accused of stealing county funds by filing time sheets for work he did not perform.

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Thomas Keller, one of America's foremost chefs, announced that on Sept. 1 he would abolish the practice of tipping at Per Se, his luxury restaurant in New York City, and replace it with a European-style service charge, I knew three groups would be opposed: customers, servers and restaurateurs. These three constituencies are all committed tipping -- as they quickly made clear on Web sites. To oppose tipping, it seems, is to be anticapitalist, and maybe even a little French. But Mr. Keller is right to move away from tipping -- and it's worth exploring why just about everyone else in the restaurant world is wrong to stick with the practice.
docs.abstract: Steven A Shaw Op-Ed article agrees with Thomas Keller's abolition of tipping at his New York City restaurant Per Se; explains why customers, servers and other restaurant owners favor tipping, and should not (M)
docs.snippet: Why service at restaurants should be included.

docs.lead_paragraph: Call it the advisory committee that keeps on giving advice. After two medical studies questioned the safety of its popular heart failure therapy Natrecor, the Scios unit of Johnson & Johnson turned in April to a technique government and business often use to make problems go away: it formed an outside advisory committee.

headline.main: Expert Panel Gives Advice That Surprises A Drug Maker

docs.abstract: Outside advisory committee formed by Scios unit of Johnson & Johnson, led by Dr Eugene Braunwald of Harvard Medical School, determined in June that use of Natrecor, Scios's popular heart failure therapy, should be strictly limited to acutely ill patients in hospitals; committee asked Scios to begin warning doctors against drug's use in outpatients, treatment that had not been approved by Food and Drug Administration but that had helped turn Natrecor into big money maker; some committee members have expressed concern about ways Scios has responded to its recommendations; Scios defends its response to Braunwald committee's recommendations and says it is preparing to expand its physician outreach campaign warning doctors against using Natrecor on outpatients (M)
docs.snippet: Call it the advisory committee that keeps on giving advice.

docs.lead_paragraph: The nation is in the grip of what looks like a terrifying melanoma epidemic: melanoma is being diagnosed at more than double the rate it was in 1986, increasing faster than any other major cancer. But why the numbers are increasing is a contentious subject, so touchy that one dermatologist called it ''the third rail of dermatology.''

headline.main: Melanoma Is Epidemic. Or Is It?

docs.snippet: Experts don't agree on whether an increase in melanoma cases means it is becoming more common or that more people are getting screened for skin cancer.

multimedia.credit: Gina Kolata of The Times discusses a new study that questions the benefits of melanoma screening programs.
multimedia.caption: Health Minute: Skin Cancer Screenings
